last_replies.com:
>>52578027
>>Do any one you still actually care?
Yeah.
>>If so what is it that you still feel draws you to the show
The reason I still care and what draws me to the anime is nostalgia. That's it, really. I started watching the anime as a kid when Pokemon was a huge part of my life, from the games to the anime to merch and stuff. Watching an episode takes me back to a more carefree and happier time in my life. It's a cozy, warm feeling, spending time with these characters as they go on adventures. It really has very little to do with the characters... except for Ash and Pikachu, since they feel like old friends at this point (yeah, I know, that sounds weird, but if it's any better, I don't treat them as real or self-insert to hang out with them or anything like that). They're familiar though. I associate happier times in my life with them, so it's my comfort, especially on days I just want to forget about all the shit that I'm having to worry about and deal with.

Old bread: >>52571179

Welcome to the Raidcat / 6 Star Tera Raid Meta Thread
Use this thread to trade for raidcats, to organize (raidcat) raids, or just to discuss and ask questions about raids in general.

>lol I can solo 5 star raids I don't need your ugly cat
6 stars are infinitely harder than 5 and extremely annoying. You can do them the normal way and risk wasting your time, or accept the raidcat as your raid savior.

>What's the meta?
4 Perrserkers. Their Hidden Ability stacks multiplicatively and, if you follow the flowchart, you can one-shot most raids.

>What's the raidcat like?
Perrserker @ Lum Berry
Level 100
Ability: Steely Spirit (Hidden Ability)
EVs: 252 Atk / 252 Speed (Host) or HP (Joiner)
Adamant Nature
- Iron Head
- Screech
- Swords Dance
- Taunt (Host) / Helping Hand (Joiner)

>Host? Joiner? Flowchart?
There's a small difference in strategy whether you are hosting or joining a raid and a specific flowchart. See OP pic.

>Does this work every time?
No, but it's one of the only consistent strategies that you can follow. It's not great against Pokemon that have strong and/or STAB Fire/Fighting/Ground moves, and if their Tera resists Steel it can also take a few more turn (but still doable).

>So what's the hype?
Catraids are simple to organize, have plenty of flowcharts, and finish the job very quickly. It's about efficiency.

>I have a question about raids...
Check OP pic.

>How to get cat with HA?
Language Teacher sidequest, then use an Ability Patch to change its ability. Patch is an 11% drop from 6 Star Raids.

>I tried breeding but I'm getting Kantonian Meowth
Make the G-Meowth hold an Everstone

>wtf I did that but none of them have Steely Spirit
G-Meowth's HA is Unnerve, it becomes Steely Spirit upon evolution.

For other viable meta strategies and mons, Ctrl+F OTHERMONS
For specific strategies, Ctrl+F HARDRAIDS

sub: I think that Legends: Arceus is better than Scarlet/Violet
com:
>vibrant colours
>cel-shading
>bad graphics, but at least has an appealing and memorable art style unlike sv
>actually took steps to advancing the pokemon gameplay formula, such as overworld catching, using your pokemon to gather materials, and faster paced battles
>better move animations
>has a ton of sidequests
>catching em all actually has a purpose now
>fun end game battle facility
>can rematch any of the major characters whenever you want
>almost every little area has unique music, unlike sv which has like 4 overworld tracks
>can actually aim your pokeball when throwing it
>the battles are actually difficult due to different stat system, move order, and forced set mode
>actually has character customization
>got free dlc with extra content
>wild pokemon actually interact with the world and eachother
>wild pokemon can play with you or attack you, and you can interact with them in different ways like starting a battle with them or throwing berries to feed them
>the player can actually die due to fall damage or pokemon attacks
>better box system
>can see shiny pokemon in menus
>shiny pokemon in the overworld have a sound and visual indicator
>ui looks miles better
>button based battle ui instead of scroll based
>apricorn ball crafting
>no tranny npcs
>all three starters are s tier design wise
>kino final boss battle
>actually has soul

name: Anonymous
com:
2 > 1 > 3 > 4 > 6 > 5 > 7 > 9 > 8

Is the most objective ranking of the games.

>2 is a true sequel that just improved everything from Gen 1, plus 2 regions, best ending, best music, and released during the late GB era (the most soulful era in gaming history)
>1 started everything, best monster designs to date, also extremely soulful, story that makes sense and isn't over-complicated, buggy/glitchy in a fun way
>3 was more of the same, but being too samey stagnated the series in the eyes of the public, ending Pokemania (but the games still stand up well if you ignore the 'culture')
>4 is where the very first cracks started to show, still good enough but some ugly designs here and there, and some bad decisions made in development like slow battles, surf speed, new evos being relegated to postgame
>6 took the first leap into 3D, but wound up a bit like Gen 3 in that it was again, a fairly standard Pokemn adventure, which wasn't enough progress at this stage
>5 started the new era of the games being handholdy, linear and brain-dead with any semblance of difficulty being surgically removed
>7 introduced long, unskippable cutscenes that interfere with the expected seamless gameplay experience that Pokemon usually has, also the beginning of the truly abhorrent new Pokemon designs
>9, while the right step forward, was rushed to market and is buggy/glitchy in a bad/disruptive way, and frankly the ugliest games to date
>8 was rushed to market unfinished, and the remainder of the game was then finished post-release and sold as DLC - the ultimate sin

If you're not being biased and were alive to experience the release of each game, this is as close as you can get to an actual ranking.

name: Anonymous
com:
"the longer it takes for them to read, the more they absorb" Edition

Welcome to the Raidcat / 6 Star Tera Raid Meta Thread
Use this thread to trade for raidcats, to organize (raidcat) raids, or just to discuss and ask questions about raids in general.

>lol I can solo 5 star raids I don't need your ugly cat
6 stars are infinitely harder than 5 and extremely annoying. You can do them the normal way and risk wasting your time, or accept the raidcat as your raid savior.
>What's the meta?
4 Perrserkers. Their Hidden Ability stacks multiplicatively and, if you follow the flowchart, you can one-shot most raids.
>What's the raidcat like?
Perrserker @ Lum Berry
Level 100
Ability: Steely Spirit (Hidden Ability)
EVs: 252 Atk / 252 Speed (Host) or HP (Joiner)
Adamant Nature
- Iron Head
- Screech
- Swords Dance
- Taunt (Host) / Helping Hand (Joiner)
>Host? Joiner? Flowchart?
There's a small difference in strategy whether you are hosting or joining a raid and a specific flowchart. See OP pic.
>Does this work every time?
No, but it's one of the only consistent strategies that you can follow. It's not great against Pokemon that have strong and/or STAB Fire/Fighting/Ground moves, and if their Tera resists Steel it can also take a few more turn (but still doable).
>So what's the hype?
Catraids are simple to organize, have plenty of flowcharts, and finish the job very quickly. It's about efficiency.
>I have a question about raids...
Check OP pic.
>How to get cat with HA?
Language Teacher sidequest, then use an Ability Patch to change its ability. Patch is an 11% drop from 6 Star Raids.
>I tried breeding but I'm getting Kantonian Meowth
Make the G-Meowth hold an Everstone
>wtf I did that but none of them have Steely Spirit
G-Meowth's HA is Unnerve, it becomes Steely Spirit upon evolution.

For other viable meta strategies and mons, Ctrl+F OTHERMONS
For specific strategies, Ctrl+F HARDRAIDS

name: Anonymous
com:
I know this isn't Pokémon-related per se, however it is related to content that was posted here, therefore I'm putting this here. I apologize if this is not an appropriate place to post this.
After looking more into the situation regarding the incomplete SMAS source code, I've come to a much different conclusion. My intial thought was that perhaps the archive's extraction process was interrupted or mishandled somehow. However now I think that's not exactly the case.

There's a file called `Backup.info` in the `NEWS_41` folder, which has 12 entries. The first of these entries has a size value of `6848`, which is very close to the extracted size of 6.71MB. This seems to suggest that it was some sort of proprietary or otherwise unknown/unusual multi-part archive file, and that only the first of the 12 parts was actually extracted.

In case you're wondering why these files are of interest, note that they are supposed to contain the source for not only All-Stars, but Super Mario World as well (since this is for the SMAS+SMW release). Hopefully that's enough of a motivation to find them (Though a large part of the SMB3 source as well as the SMB2 source are also missing as well. Only SMB1 and Lost Levels are currently present in their entirety).

Which is why I'm asking anyone who has information on the team behind the original leaks, or anyone who may have information on the files' whereabouts, to please come forward with that information. Hopefully someone has information on where they can be found, or can provide these original files as well.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Crap, it seems 4chan ate the spacing after the first paragraph... Anyways...
I know that the warez scene and the preservation scene disagree on how files like these should be treated. The former is heavily revolved around cracking things, and releasing uncracked content is greatly frowned upon. Whereas the latter is all about preserving old or lost media for future generations, and heavily dislikes when files like these are hoarded, especially among collector types.

As someone who leans more toward the latter, I'd greatly appreciated it if these files were to be preserved, and perhaps so their contents could be analyzed by people who are more familiar with such systems.

There seems to be a running theme in the game that people question whether the paradox pokemon are actually pokemon when seeing or hearing about them for the first time. Even in Scarlet where the paradoxes are obviously living creatures, people in universe can apparently tell something is off about them. People aside from Penny, who mistakes Scream Tail/Iron Bundle for a regular Jigglypuff/Delibird at first glance and only wonders what it is after the battle.

As an aside, while going through the game text I noticed that the paradox pokemon have anime-ish cries where they say their name in dialogue boxes, sort of. Rather, they say the name of the pokemon they're based on, or part of it.
Great Tusk
>Dooon! Faaahnd!
Iron Treads
>Whirrr! Don-fah!
Scream Tail
>Puuu?
>Pu.
>PurrraAAAAAGH!
Iron Bundle
>Deli?
>De.
>Dededede-li-li-BIIIIIIRD!

It's weird since the games don't usually do anime cries, but also shows that there's still a connection to the original pokemon there.

last_replies.com:
Espathra @ Mirror Herb/Covert Cloak
Opportunist/Speed Boost
Tera: Psychic
-Lumina Crash
-Dazzling Gleam
-Roost/Calm Mind
-Filler/Stored Power
Lumina Crash is a 80BP stab move that also lowers the target's sp.def by 2 stages it's insane. Any sp.atk users on your team will love you. You also have the usual calm mind stored power set, but beware for the raid to take away your boosts. Clear Amulet doesn't work. Opportunist + Mirror Herb for a one-time double boost when the raidmon uses boosting moves, Covert Cloak for things like nuzzle. Most of the time you'll be spamming Lumina Crash. Biggest con is it's somewhat frail, so look out for super effective moves.

>>52575050
Real question, but what level design? Relatively flat open world areas are intentionally not crafted like a "level." The two are antithetical.

IIRC there isn't a single dungeon in Paldea , unless you count the Gym minigames

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>52575179
Level design doesn’t need to be super dense or restrictive, especially not in an OPEN world game, what matters is that the world design forces you to consciously navigate and interact with it in ways that impact the experience. As you can see from picrel, the map is actually deceptively linear for an open world game, forcing you to zigzag through the geographical obstacles like mountains, rivers, lakes etc, in order to get around. This naturally funnels the player through each area, and prevents people from just running straight across the map in a few min, which helps make the region feel bigger.
Yes, the pokeride abilities collectively let you straight up bypass all these level design elements, but you need to unlock those by beating the Titans, many of which are on the other side of the map, so you’ll inevitably need to explore at least a chunk of the map without them. I just think your idea of level design is too narrow, my biggest fears when I heard SV was open world was that the whole map would be completely explorable right away and nothing about my navigation abilities would change as I progressed. Not only was this not true, but the world was also just denser designed than I was expecting, so I’m very relieved personally, they went open world without sacrificing what I actually liked about the linear world design, which was unlocking new areas like a Metroidvania and needing to take specified naturally formed paths to get to certain isolated areas (I especially like how all the final 3 gyms are located in the most difficult to reach parts of the map
